Prompt:
I need to do the following: select the last layer in the layer editor

The webapp has the following DOM Tree Structure (simplified + only human visible elements):
```
BODY
---DIV
---HEADER
------A (aria-label: "Field Maps Designer home page") > svg > path
------DIV
------NAV (aria-label: "Breadcrumb") > OL
------------LI > A > "Maps"
------------LI
---------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------LI (aria-label: "Map title: “suffragium volaticus vehemens addo”") > "suffragium volaticus vehemens addo"
------DIV > UL
------------LI > DIV > CALCITE-DROPDOWN
---------------------... > DIV > DIV
---------------------CALCITE-BUTTON
------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON
---------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------SPAN
------------------------"local"
------------LI > A > "Resources"
------------DIV
------------LI > DIV > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------DIV > DIV > "CL"
------------------------SPAN > "Charlotte"
---MAIN > DIV > DIV
------------CALCITE-ACTION-BAR
---------------... > CALCITE-ACTION-GROUP
---------------------... > DIV
---------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Collapse")
---------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------DIV > "Collapse"
---------------CALCITE-ACTION-GROUP
------------------... > DIV
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Overview")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Overview"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Forms")

------------------------------DIV > "Forms"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Geofences")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Geofences"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Offline")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Offline"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "App settings")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "App settings"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Sharing")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Sharing"
---------------CALCITE-ACTION-MENU
------------------...
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Open")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Open"
---------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "What’s New (Indicator present)")
---------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------DIV > "What’s New"
------------DIV

------------------INPUT

---------------DIV
------------------CALCITE-BLOCK
---------------------... > DIV > ARTICLE
------------------------------DIV > BUTTON

------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path

---------------------------CALCITE-LABEL
------------------------------... > DIV
------------------------------"Framifurt"
---------------------------DIV
------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg
------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------CALCITE-BLOCK > ... > DIV > ARTICLE > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------------------HEADER > DIV > H3 > "Tables"
------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------CALCITE-BLOCK > ... > DIV > ARTICLE > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------------------HEADER > DIV > H3 > "Basemap"
------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------CALCITE-SPLIT-BUTTON > ... > DIV > DIV
---------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON
------------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON > SPAN
------------------------------"Add layers"
---------------------------DIV > DIV
---------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN
------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Add existing layers or create new layers") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------DIV > DIV
------------------svg > path
------------------DIV > "Canvas is empty"
------------------DIV > "Select an item in the Forms panel to configure its templates and form."
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the last layer in the layer editor"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the last layer in the layer editor 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```
---

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the last layer in the layer editor' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
unknown 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "The last layer in the layer editor, 'Framifurt', is marked as selected in the updated DOM structure, indicating that the agent successfully selected this layer.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('tab').locator('span', { hasText: 'Tasks' })"}
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - content related to creating layouts is now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "After the action, the content related to creating layouts is now visible, indicating that the 'Tasks' tab was selected. The presence of the message 'Create layouts to configure actions' and the button 'New layout' supports this claim.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByText('New layout', { exact: true })"}
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - the canvas has a new layout card
    - empty canvas instructions are removed. 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "The DOM after the interaction shows a new layout card labeled 'New layout' has been added to the canvas, and the previous empty canvas instructions have been removed. This indicates that the action to select the button labeled 'New Layout' was successfully performed.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN').locator('CALCITE-BUTTON[aria-label=\"Layout options menu\"]')"}
```

------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Layout options menu") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card 

Avoid selectors that may cause these Errors; try different ones:
```
Bad response; led to error: TimeoutError: locator.waitFor: Timeout 5000ms exceeded.
Call log:
  [2m- waiting for locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN').locator('CALCITE-BUTTON[aria-label="Layout options menu"]').first() to be visible[22m

```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN').locator('CALCITE-BUTTON').getByLabel('Layout options menu')"}
```
---

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - options to remove and duplicate for the first layout card are now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

}
```

------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Undo: Create layout") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Save") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN
---------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
---------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------CALCITE-TAB
------------------------... > DIV > SECTION
------------------------DIV > FA-INDEX-VIEW > FA-LAYOUTS-LIST > DIV
------------------------------------DIV
---------------------------------------DIV
------------------------------------------FA-LAYOUTS-DROPDOWN > CALCITE-LABEL
------------------------------------------------... > DIV
------------------------------------------------DIV
---------------------------------------------------SPAN > "Layouts"
---------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON (aria-label: "information icon") > ... > svg > path
------------------------------------------------CALCITE-COMBOBOX > ... > DIV
---------------------------------------------------------DIV
------------------------------------------------------------DIV
---------------------------------------------------------------LABEL > "Layouts"
---------------------------------------------------------------SPAN > SPAN > "All"
------------------------------------------------------------SPAN > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------------------------------UL
------------------------------------------------------------LI > "All"
------------------------------------------------------------LI > "New layout"
------------------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-BUTTON
------------------------------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON
---------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------------------------------SPAN
------------------------------------------------"New layout"
---------------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-BUTTON
---------------------------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------------------------------SPAN
---------------------------------------------"Task filters"
------------------------------------FACE-SORTABLE-LIST
---------------------------------------... > SECTION
---------------------------------------FACE-SORTABLE-LIST-ITEM
------------------------------------------... > DIV
------------------------------------------FA-LAYOUT-CARD > CALCITE-CARD
------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV > SECTION
------------------------------------------------------------HEADER > DIV
------------------------------------------------------------DIV
------------------------------------------------------------FOOTER
------------------------------------------------DIV
---------------------------------------------------SPAN > "New layout"
---------------------------------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN
------------------------------------------------------... > DIV
------------------------------------------------------------DIV
------------------------------------------------------------DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Layout options menu") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN-GROUP
---------------------------------------------------------... > DIV
---------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN-ITEM
------------------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
---------------------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------------------------------------------SPAN
------------------------------------------------------------"Remove"
---------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN-ITEM
------------------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
---------------------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------------------------------------------SPAN
------------------------------------------------------------"Duplicate"
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the button to duplicate the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the button to duplicate the first layout card 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN-ITEM').locator('span', { hasText: 'Duplicate' })"}
```

 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the button to duplicate the first layout card 

Avoid selectors that may cause these Errors; try different ones:
```
Bad response; led to error: TimeoutError: locator.waitFor: Timeout 5000ms exceeded.
Call log:
  [2m- waiting for locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN-ITEM').locator('span').filter({ hasText: 'Duplicate' }).first() to be visible[22m

Bad response; led to error: TimeoutError: locator.waitFor: Timeout 5000ms exceeded.
Call log:
  [2m- waiting for locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN-ITEM').locator('span').filter({ hasText: 'Duplicate' }).first() to be visible[22m

```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN-ITEM').locator('span').filter({ hasText: 'Duplicate' }).first()"}
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the button to duplicate the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```

// getByLabel

// getByText

// getByTestID

// XPath:

// CSS:

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'click the button to duplicate the first layout card' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - there is now a second layout card
    - the second layout card is labeled that it is a copy of the first 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```
{
    "Explanation": "After the action, there is now a second layout card labeled 'Copy of New layout', indicating that the duplication of the first layout card was successful.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click on the first layout card 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('FACE-SORTABLE-LIST-ITEM:nth-of-type(1) > DIV > FA-LAYOUT-CARD > CALCITE-CARD')"}
```

------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV > SECTION
------------------------------------------------------------HEADER > DIV
------------------------------------------------------------DIV
------------------------------------------------------------FOOTER
------------------------------------------------DIV
---------------------------------------------------SPAN > "Copy of New layout"
---------------------------------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN
------------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Layout options menu") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click on the first layout card 

Avoid selectors that may cause these Errors; try different ones:
```
Bad response; led to error: TimeoutError: locator.waitFor: Timeout 5000ms exceeded.
Call log:
  [2m- waiting for locator('FACE-SORTABLE-LIST-ITEM:nth-of-type(1) > DIV > FA-LAYOUT-CARD > CALCITE-CARD').first() to be visible[22m

```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('FACE-SORTABLE-LIST-ITEM:nth-of-type(1) > DIV > FA-LAYOUT-CARD > CALCITE-CARD')"}
```

{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click on the first layout card 

Avoid selectors that may cause these Errors; try different ones:
```

  [2m- waiting for locator('FACE-SORTABLE-LIST-ITEM:nth-of-type(1) > DIV > FA-LAYOUT-CARD > CALCITE-CARD').first() to be visible[22m

------------------DIV > "Canvas is empty"
------------------DIV > "Select an item in the Forms panel to configure its templates and form."
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The number of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, etc.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the last layer in the layer editor"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 - we will always add a .first() locator to find the first matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the last layer in the layer editor 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)').first()"}
```

------------------------------------LI > DIV > DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------DL > DT > "Date and time"
------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON["aria-hidden:undefined->true","icon:undefined->calendar","calcite-hydrated:undefined->''"] > ... > svg > path
------------------------------------LI > DIV > DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------DL
---------------------------------------------------DT > "Number - Double"
---------------------------------------------------DD > "Decimal, e.g. 1.2"
------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON["aria-hidden:undefined->true","icon:undefined->number","calcite-hydrated:undefined->''"] > ... > svg > path
------------------------------------LI > DIV > DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------DL
---------------------------------------------------DT > "Number - Integer"
---------------------------------------------------DD > "Whole, e.g. 1"
------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON["aria-hidden:undefined->true","icon:undefined->integer","calcite-hydrated:undefined->''"] > ... > svg > path

------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON["aria-hidden:undefined->true","icon:undefined->form-field-multiline","calcite-hydrated:undefined->''"] > ... > svg > path

------------------------------------------------DL > DT > "Text - Single line"
------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON["aria-hidden:undefined->true","icon:undefined->form-field","calcite-hydrated:undefined->''"] > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------H5 > "Choice"
---------------------------------OL
------------------------------------LI > DIV > DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------DL > DT > "Combo box"

------------------------------------------------DL > DT > "Switch"
------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON["aria-hidden:undefined->true","icon:undefined->toggle","calcite-hydrated:undefined->''"] > ... > svg > path
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the last layer in the layer editor' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
unknown 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

---

    "Explanation": "The last layer in the layer editor, 'North Vladimirworth', is marked as selected in the updated DOM structure, indicating that the agent successfully selected this layer.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The number of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, etc.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 - we will always add a .first() locator to find the first matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('tab').locator('span', { hasText: 'Tasks' }).first()"}
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - content related to creating layouts is now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "After the action, the content related to creating layouts is now visible, indicating that the 'Tasks' tab was successfully selected. The presence of the 'Create layouts to configure actions' message and the 'New layout' button supports this claim.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The number of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, etc.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 - we will always add a .first() locator to find the first matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByText('New layout', { exact: true }).first()"}
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - the canvas has a new layout card
    - empty canvas instructions are removed. 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "The DOM after the action shows a new layout card with the label 'New layout' present in the canvas, indicating that the action to select the button labeled 'New Layout' was performed. Additionally, the empty canvas instructions have been removed, which further supports that the action was successfully completed.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The number of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, etc.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 - we will always add a .first() locator to find the first matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card 

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN').locator('CALCITE-BUTTON[aria-label=\"Layout options menu\"]')"}
```

---------------------------------... > DIV > DIV

---------------------------------------------------SPAN > "New layout"

------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Layout options menu") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The number of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, etc.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example when they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or may have spelling mistakes.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
Minimize the number of chained locators while maintaining specificity accurate to the DOM.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCIT-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use { exact: true } and consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - Get the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .locator('nth=4')
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other selectors; if needed use chaining instead
 - we will always add a .first() locator to find the first matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" to get the first matching element in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.

Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card 

Avoid selectors that may cause these Errors; try different ones:
```
Bad response; led to error: TimeoutError: locator.waitFor: Timeout 5000ms exceeded.
Call log:
  [2m- waiting for locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN').locator('CALCITE-BUTTON[aria-label="Layout options menu"]').first() to be visible[22m

```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('CALCITE-DROPDOWN').locator('CALCITE-BUTTON').first()"}
```

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'click the dropdown menu button on the first layout card' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - options to remove and duplicate for the first layout card are now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 2: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

    "Score": 1
}
```

------------------------------------HEADER > DIV > H3 > "Layers"

------------------------------... > DIV

------------------------------"Add layers"
---------------------------DIV > DIV

------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path

------------------------------------------------------------DIV

------------------------------------------------------------SPAN > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path

------------------------------------------------------------LI > "All"

---------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path

---------------------------------------... > SECTION
